entry.title: Connecting SAP Cloud Integration with Salesforce

link.title: Connecting SAP Cloud Integration with Salesforce

entry.content:
I found an excellent blog, that describes how SAP Cloud Integration can be used to integrate into Salesforce.

This looks unnecessary complex to me. I have never worked with SAP Cloud Integration, but with a number of other integration tools, where I did a lot more (real life integration of complex business processes) than what is shown in this blog and it was much simpler. But I guess SAP customers are used to this and don’t question it. In 2022, software should be better than this!

The two parts of the blog can be found here:

  • SAP Cloud Integration with Salesforce – Part 1
  • SAP Cloud Integration with Salesforce – Part 2

entry.title: SAP - still inconsistent after 50 years
entry.content:
I know that I am complaining about small, minor things here, but please explain me this:

What does the dialog titles “Hit List 17 Entries” and “Table Row 40 Entries” tell me? Nothing! This is from transaction VA02 (edit sales order) for Inco Terms (left) and Payment Terms (right). I wonder why something like this shipped in the first place and why it was not considered a bug in every single release that went out the door since then.

There are three films and three tv shows with the name “The Hit List”, but I doubt SAP is referring to any of them …

entry.title: Two Types of Developers
entry.content:
I had the plesure to work with two types of developers.

Type one is doing what you ask them to do (at most). Sometimes not even that. As I am far away from being perfect, I make mistakes, I write imperfect tickets and specs. The result? Garbage in, garbage out.

Type two is questioning what I ask them to do. They propose alternative solutions, they tell me when my tickets are shit and they convert my garbage into something useful.

I am thankful that I can work with type two at the moment.

entry.title: The best computer I have ever used

link.title: The best computer I have ever used

entry.content:
Since January I am working with the new 16” MacBook Pro, M1 Max CPU and 64 GB RAM. I have 3 external displays connected and I wonder if the fan is broken. I think I never heard it once. In my old - just one generation old - MacBook Pro, the fan was running nonestop when I connected two external displays. My current laptop is clearly the best computer I have ever used.

It comes with a great keyboard, good enough speakers, a fantastic display and all the ports I need.
